This is my observation of the week (and a reminder for all sales leaders!) 🤓 𝗥𝗲𝗺𝗶𝗻𝗱𝗲𝗿: Don't neglect coaching your sales team. This week, I started coaching a sales team specifically on discovery and demos. Here are 3 things I noticed this week and with other customers before, and how to avoid them: 1. 𝗣𝗿𝗼𝘀𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝘀 𝗴𝗲𝘁 𝗶𝗺𝗽𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗲𝗻𝘁, 𝗮𝗻𝗱 𝘀𝗮𝗹𝗲𝘀 𝗿𝗲𝗽𝘀 𝗳𝗲𝗲𝗹 𝗿𝘂𝘀𝗵𝗲𝗱 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝘁𝗮𝗿𝘁 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗺𝗼. 2. 𝗙𝗲𝗮𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗲 𝗱𝘂𝗺𝗽𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗱𝘂𝗿𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗱𝗲𝗺𝗼, 𝘁𝗿𝘆𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝗼 𝘀𝗵𝗼𝘄 𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗺 𝗮𝗹𝗹. 3. 𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝘁𝘂𝗿𝗻𝘀 𝗼𝘂𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗯𝗲 𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗲. 🤷‍♂️ To be honest, I experienced this early in my career too. And this is a reality for many SaaS companies. 👉 That's why coaching is so important. 👉 Most sales reps really want to get better; they just need some help. So, how do you avoid the three things mentioned above? Here are some quick strategies: 1. 𝗔𝗹𝗶𝗴𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗲𝘅𝗽𝗲𝗰𝘁𝗮𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀: - Start with a clear, customer-centric goal for the meeting and ask for confirmation (and what else to add). - Share a clear agenda on how to achieve the goal and ask for input. 2 𝗗𝗶𝗮𝗴𝗻𝗼𝘀𝗲 𝗳𝗶𝗿𝘀𝘁: - Uncover pain and peel that onion (no happy ears, peel that onion). - Ask your prospect to prioritize their pains (especially when you've uncovered many). That way, you can focus your demo on showing the parts that help solve the pain. - Make sure your sales reps understand the world of their ICP and personas and feel comfortable talking about it, the product should not be their only comfort zone. 3. "𝗣𝗿𝗶𝗰𝗲 𝗶𝘀 𝗼𝗻𝗹𝘆 𝗮𝗻 𝗶𝘀𝘀𝘂𝗲 𝗶𝗻 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗮𝗯𝘀𝗲𝗻𝗰𝗲 𝗼𝗳 𝘃𝗮𝗹𝘂𝗲." - Uncover the impact > what value do you bring by solving their pains? - Don't assume your prospect knows what their pain costs them or what value you can bring, talk about it (selling = helping buyers buy). What's your observation from coaching your team this week? BTW. Need help with your sales team? Feel free to send me a DM and get in touch! …see more
Email Marketing for B2B: Best Practices for Success 📧💼 Effective B2B email marketing hinges on personalization and relevance. Start by segmenting your email list to target specific industries, job roles, or company sizes. Craft compelling subject lines to capture attention and ensure your content is valuable, addressing pain points or offering solutions. 📈 Use a professional yet engaging tone, and always include a clear call-to-action (CTA). Regularly test and optimize your emails by experimenting with different designs, copy, and send times. 📊 Automation can streamline your campaigns, allowing you to send timely and personalized messages based on user behavior. Ensure your emails are mobile-friendly, as many professionals check emails on the go. 📱 Lastly, analyze your results to refine your strategy continuously. Open rates, click-through rates, and conversions are key metrics to monitor. Successful B2B email marketing builds strong relationships and drives business growth. 🚀 Happy emailing! 📨 …see more
The art of persuasion in sales is no longer selling the product but understanding the opportunity that the product creates or the problem it solves. Today's B2B buyers are more informed, more independent, and more in control than ever before. To remain competitive, software and SaaS companies must adapt to these changes and focus on meeting buyers' needs rather than their own. Read on 👇 …see more
You know the way your buyers buy has changed, and your playbooks don't work anymore. But leadership (and, eventually, sales) don't want to accept the reality and change. Here are 3 layers of proof and reasoning we use to change that mindset: 1. BUYER JOURNEY OF EXISTING CLIENTS. Start with interviewing recent closed won deals. - How did they become aware of you? - Did they check any marketing content before becoming a client? - What internal discussions did they have and how they presented your product? - Why did they decide to buy? - How they typically do vendor research and evaluation? Collect and present different touchpoints. 2. CURRENT PLAYBOOKS' PERFORMANCE. Analyse revenue, pipeline, pipeline velocity and revenue metrics Average Contract Value Win rate Sales cycle length # of sales opportunities (not discovery calls) Expansion deals Payback Account to pipeline ratio (how many accounts that were targeted became sales opportunities) for the last 36 months. Next, analyze and categorize lost reasons. Then, create diagrams to present declining pipeline and revenue. 3. INDUSTRY CASE STUDIES. Interview or talk to consultants and marketing agencies that work with your industry, or non-competing companies that made a change you want. - Why did they decide to make a change? - What are their core activities and why do they run them? - Before / after results ---- Change management is hard. You can do it only with data and social proof. But don't stop here. Wrap up everything in a short presentation explaining WHY to change now, your suggested transformation and a detailed pilot program. --- This Thursday we invited our client to share how he was able to make the change management and transform Go-To-Market strategy of . As a result, in 6 months the marketing-sourced pipeline went from 35% to 60%. Save your spot here: …see more

Sales teams - please STOP blaming Marketing for bad leads I see too many companies bringing in a Head of Marketing to generate leads And then be disappointed by spammy, poor quality, poor-fit, too-early leads That just waste everyone's time. Marketing is doing the job you asked of them. (That's Step 1) BUT there's something key missing At the COMPANY that is causing this misalignment. Now it's time for Step 2: Add a Scoring Model to your systems to weed out the best-fit leads from the chaff. - Redefine the MQL threshold (maybe it should be higher) - Set up the buying unit's Personas in your CRM - Add your behavior Scoring Model to the CRM - Add your ICP match Scoring Model to the CRM - Add your Target Account list to the CRM + Bonus Points: Add a gated demo on your website (Try , , or if you're a startup, or if you're more established) -Create reports that prove lead quality (based on the above) - Create routing rules in your systems: --Send poor-fit leads a "sorry we're not the best fit - here are some resources instead" email --Place okay-fit leads on nurture outreach sequences (for later) --Route great-fit leads to a Sales demo The main reason why the misalignment happened is because the teams never agreed on "good lead" criteria. And didn't program it (using quantifiable, measurable attributes) in your systems Didn't battle-test and confirm it with reality Didn't create the charts and reports MEASURING lead quality. Create Sales & Marketing alignment, and generate more revenue, quicker - with the right leads for you. …see more
Should employers and employees reinvent the (bicycle) wheel? Monday 3 June was World Cycling Day, celebrating a simple means of transportation that has been around for more than two centuries. Cycling is also one of the most sustainable ways to get around, with bikes being a clean, simple and long-lasting product. As such, encouraging more people to cycle could be a gamechanger for the climate. In the Netherlands, people cycle an average of 2.6 kilometres per day and use their bike for one in four trips. If that became the global standard, the world would see carbon emissions decrease by 686 million tonnes - that's more than the entire carbon footprint of Germany or the UK. Biking is also a great way to get in some daily exercise and boost your health. Compared to a non-active commute, cycling to work has been found to lower the risk of cancer and heart disease by 45% and 46%, respectively. Bike-to-work schemes are therefore a great way for employers to boost their sustainability credentials and keep their workforce healthy. Belgium, the Netherlands, France and some Italian cities including Florence and Bari are literally paying people to commute by bike, as workers receive a "mileage allowance" for every kilometre they cycle to work and back. While paid by businesses, employers can deduct this money from their tax bill. One in five people employed by Belgian small and medium-sized enterprises earned this bicycle allowance in the first half of 2022, reports. Elsewhere, policies are intended to lower the cost of cycling equipment. Luxembourg residents who ride their bike to work can deduct up to €300 from their personal income tax and use that money to buy a new two-wheeler. In the UK, it's more common for workers to acquire a bike through their employer and get part of the money back in tax deductions. ✍️ Sources: …see more
95% of customers read online reviews before buying a product 94% say reviews have made them avoid a business Google hosts 73% of all online reviews for businesses - Focus on Google Reviews - Encourage Positive Reviews From Customers - Engage with Feedback - Monitor Regularly …see more

🔍 "Go Small in Large Accounts" – The Game-Changer for Tech Sales! 💡 Attention Sales Leaders and Professionals in Tech! 🚀 Are you looking to maximize your impact within large accounts? Instead of spreading your efforts thin, focus on high-impact segments within these giants. Here's how: 🎯 Segment Smartly: Identify and prioritize segments with the highest potential. Look for departments eager to adopt new technologies and those with substantial IT budgets. Think R&D, IT infrastructure, Application development and Management , or cybersecurity. 📋 Tailored Engagement: Develop customized value propositions that directly address the unique challenges and goals of each segment. Create content that speaks their language – be it whitepapers, case studies, or webinars. 👥 Build Strong Relationships: Assign dedicated account teams who are experts in areas like cloud computing, cybersecurity, or data analytics. Regular touchpoints are key to maintaining trust and staying on top of evolving needs. 📊 Leverage Tech & Data: Utilize CRM systems and data analytics tools to gather insights and track engagement. Predictive analytics can forecast future needs, allowing you to stay one step ahead. 📈 Measure and Improve: Define clear KPIs and regularly review your performance. Continuous feedback loops will help you refine your approach and innovate based on real-world insights. By "going small" in large accounts, you'll drive significant growth and value, making a bigger impact with a more focused approach. Ready to transform your sales strategy? Let's go small to win big! 🌟 --- Rajeev Karkhanis, CCXP …see more

Brad Pitt and I are not dating. And your leads are not deals. I've identified Brad as a lead...but does Brad know who I am? Has he agreed to talk to me or take me on a date? No! The same is true of your fantasy prospective customers. I absolutely encourage you to build a list of these target companies and people, but they are not 'deals' until someone responds with the intent to learn more or buy. Pipeline structure and management are two of the biggest things I see so many startups get wrong. And it's not that hard to get right. ❌ They create deals (aka opportunities) when they identify a lead....not when someone has actually expressed interest and intent to buy. ❌ Their deal stages are a mess. They have too many stages, or they have a stage for 'on hold' where deals go to die, which throws off their conversions. ❌ They have 45 pipelines 🤯 ❌ They don't consistently move deals through the funnel using objective exit criteria or put bumper rails in place to hold people accountable. ❌ They don't consistently track key data on their deals that helps inform their forecast or future refinement of positioning, targeting, marketing, and more. You don't need a big budget or 12 tools for this. You need 1 tool - a CRM. And you need to clearly document your sales stages with objective exit criteria and systematically hold people accountable to follow the process as designed. That's it. That's all you have to do to obtain meaningful pipeline metrics that should inform so many critical aspects of your go-to-market. This also should* be something you get right from the very. beginning. of. time. Starting with your founder led sales motion. You'll thank me later. This is what I'm talking about ALL month long in my newsletter. Get on da list. 👀 ________________________ If you don't know me well, I'm Jess 👋 . Fractional CRO + CMO and Transition expert. Making go-to-market simple(r) and scalable for and sales reps, one at a time. …see more
En France : “Je télécharge l’ebook gratuit pour pas payer :)” Aux US : “Je check l’ebook pour voir si j’investis ou pas.” En France : “J’ai acheté le produit à 500€ pour éviter de payer celui à 5000€.” Aux US : “J’achète le produit à 500€ pour voir si le 5000€ vaut le coup.” En France : “Je suis satisfait mais je préfère continuer seul (pour me prouver des trucs).” Aux US : “Bien sûr qu’on continue la collab’ : je suis satisfait :)” En France : “Je change de presta tous les 3 mois. Question de principe.” Aux US : “On change pas une équipe qui gagne.” En France : “Tout euro sorti est une dépense.” Aux US : “Le résultat est ce qui différencie la dépense de l’investissement.” Simples observations empiriques. J’ai choisi d’entreprendre en France, et j’en suis fier. Mais il y a certaines disparités culturelles qu’on ne peut ignorer. …see more See translation
There are 2 ways to run B2B ads: The easy way (Identify a channel and launch ads as quickly as possible). The hard way (Conduct extensive customer research and then launch). Ironically, the easy way is the hard way. You’ll end up launching ads based on assumptions, running around in circles, and ultimately throwing money down the drain. Then you'll blame your failure on channels, creatives, copy, the market, etc. The hard way is the easy way. It starts, and ends, with your customer. It’s as simple as that. …see more

En moyenne, chacun de ces travailleurs a réalisé 100 jours de détachement en France. Cela représente donc 20 millions de journées travaillées par les salariés détachés en 2021. I always advise my clients to reach out to new followers. Especially if they match their ICP or they’re in the same niche. The reasons? 1. A follow from your ICP is pretty much a digital hand raise saying “I’m interested in what you say or do” (Ask yourself why you click follow on other creators…it’s one of those 2 isn’t it?) But don’t reach out to pitch your service. Instead visit their profile to learn about them, Then ask how it’s going in their market or industry. 2. You build your future network by developing relationships in your niche. A few of my most recent clients were referrals from other creators in mine. And I make sure to return the favor when there’s an opportunity. Never forget the compounding effect of networking. It’s a long-term game. The most effective processes are always the simplest. All you gotta do is take action. -- 🔷Want to write more engaging content in just 3 days? Take my free 3-Day Content Writing Challenge. Salespeople 🚀 1️⃣ Avoid creating false urgency on cold calls; you can't control the prospect's timeline. 2️⃣ Pushing for meetings often backfires; focus on sparking interest instead. 3️⃣ Ask when the issue you solve will become a higher priority for the prospect. 4️⃣ Let prospects share their timeline to understand their needs better. 5️⃣ This approach shifts you from being a pest to an informed seller, making prospects more likely to engage and buy from you. …see more

As an email marketing agency, we send a lot of emails across clients (15 Million last year, and on track to almost double that this year). By far the biggest element in successful email marketing is deliverability: If emails aren't reaching your audience, then it doesn't matter what the offer is or how well it was designed. Here's a blog post we wrote a few months ago: What happens when you click send. I wrote this because I think when you understand the journey an email makes, the whole topic of deliverability starts to make sense. And the best news: is that there are fixes at every step along the way and that deliverability is entirely solvable. Hope you enjoy it! Have you ever had deliverability issues and how did you fix them? Fellow marketers, what would you add to this list? …see more
In 2000, Palm was valued higher than Apple, Amazon, Google, and Nvidia all together > Palm pioneered the personal digital assistant (PDA) market with the PalmPilot. The PalmPilot featured a calendar, address book, and memo pad, making it popular among professionals and tech enthusiasts. > Palm developed its own operating system, Palm OS, known for its intuitive interface and efficient use of memory. > Palm's market capitalization reached $58 billion. > 10 years later, Palm struggled to adapt to the rise of smartphones with touchscreens and internet access. The company's slow adoption of new technologies led to a loss of market share. Palm brand was discontinued in August 2011. > The story of Palm serves as a reminder that today's tech leader can become tomorrow's trivia answer. It also emphasizes the transient nature of success in the tech industry. How can we make ourselves and our organizations become IRREPLACEABLE? Join our new Academy & Community: …see more

The worst sales email I've seen started like this.... Hi. My name is [FRIST NAME]. I work for [Company], and we [INSERT SOLUTION]. YIKES! Years ago, I worked at a startup selling a SaaS solution to companies that didn't necessarily know they needed our software. I was able to close deals with , , and large consulting firms. Why? I helped them solve problems that they couldn't solve on their own. Most of all, I made it about them. You can do the same thing with a sales email. Start with them. For example... Instead of "Hi, my name is Steve. I work for Joe's Software," try... "Hey, Bob. Congrats on the recent acquisition." "Hey, Bob. Your presentation about X resonated with me. [insert question]" "Hey, Bob. ICYMI, this WSJ article is exactly what you said in our call." "Hey, Bob. When we spoke, you said X. Thought this might be of interest." There are a ton of great strategies out there for email. That said, what's always worked for me is to start with them - not me. Any other ideas or thoughts? What strategies and techniques have worked for you? …see more
Could This Be Why You're Being Ghosted? A Tale of Winging It vs. Planning Imagine you're setting sail on a bright, sunny day. The sea is calm, the wind is perfect, and you're ready for an adventure. You decide to wing it—no plan, just following your instincts. Sounds thrilling, right? But what happens when the weather suddenly changes? Without a plan, you're left reacting to the waves, hoping your instincts will guide you to safety. More often than not, you end up off course, struggling to regain control. In sales, winging it feels natural— 98% of reps do it. It's intuitive and doesn't require much thought. But here's the brutal truth: it usually doesn't work. Think about it. When you wing it, you react instead of being proactive. You end up doing what the client wants, like sending a proposal without understanding their real needs. And 95% of the time, they ghost you. Why? Because there's a lot of courage required to come with suggestions of buying these days. Who really wants to take a risk on how they'll be seen if an initiative they brought fails? Status quo feels safer, which is exactly why we're here—to identify the reasons behind their requests and navigate them to what will truly help them make the desired change. So how do you stop being ghosted after proposals? It all starts by measures- as each action needs to be compare against: Step 1: Analyze how all conversations that asked for a proposal have landed. Step 2: Test how much time you invest in setting a proposal out. Step 3: Ask your buyers what exactly they expect to see in the proposal. Step 4: Run a report on all the answers you get and make sure you address those queries proactively in your next meetings. Step 5: Analyze the results and compare. Before the change, 60% of the buyers we shared a proposal with didn't move forward. Can you guess what the outcome was after we followed these steps? …see more

As a B2B Lead Generation Professional, you know your customers inside out. But do you know your customer's customer? (This is the key to unlocking next-level engagement and growth) Here's why understanding your customer's customer is crucial: 📍Deeper Insights: By understanding your customer's customer, you gain valuable insights into their pain points and needs. This allows you to tailor your solutions more effectively. 📍Enhanced Value Proposition: When you know the end customer, you can position your product or service as a direct solution to their specific challenges, making your offerings more attractive. 📍Stronger Relationships: Demonstrating knowledge of your customer's ecosystem builds trust and strengthens relationships. Customers feel understood and valued, leading to long-term partnerships. 📍Competitive Edge: Many businesses overlook this critical step. By taking the time to understand the entire value chain, you differentiate yourself from competitors and position your business as a true partner, not just a vendor. (Here's how to start understanding your customer's customer) 🤯⚡🤩Ask the Right Questions: During your discovery phase, inquire about your customer’s target audience, needs, and challenges. 🤯⚡🤩Analyze Data: Utilize data analytics tools to track end-customer behavior and trends. This data is a goldmine for crafting targeted strategies. 🤯⚡🤩Engage Directly: Whenever possible, engage directly with your customer's customers through surveys, feedback forms, or even joint webinars. 🤯⚡🤩Collaborate: Work closely with your customers to co-create solutions that address the end customer's needs. This collaborative approach can drive innovation and success for all parties involved. Remember, when you understand your customer's customers, you can create more impactful solutions, build stronger relationships, and stand out in the competitive B2B landscape. P.S. Repost this tip to your network ♻️ and elevate our B2B strategies together! Which strategy will you implement first to understand your customer's customer? Comment below! …see more

Top Strategies for Generating Qualified B2B Leads: - Cold calling no longer cuts it - Decision-makers want personalized content - Quality over quantity when it comes to leads - Automation can streamline but not replace human touch Sticking to old methods is impractical – it means: - Not understanding evolving buyer demands - Failing to innovate - Missing a solid long-term plan Here’s what you MUST do to generate qualified B2B leads: - Deeply know your target market; - Tailor your strategy to fit the buying journey; - Use focused tactics for effective lead generation. This is the (anti-)pattern and I see it in my own engineers at times (because it is human nature). A story about how UK Borders chose to in-house the successful post-Brexit border solution after 3 years because of budget pressure. It beggars belief to think that something vital can be done more cheaply in-house that a company does for a living with a massive amortized R&D base - meaning you pay some small fraction of the actually costs of development and operations. Yesterday I learned the origin of Platform One was an effort to avoid paying $19M/year in licenses to a platform-as-a-service company (and to avoid feeling locked-in). Now Platform One is ~150 FTEs (~$50-70M/year est cost fully loaded and now your are mentally and technically locked-in). It happens as much in the commercial world as the government world. But in the commercial world, your competitors will pounce upon your folly and strike (see Predix). That same feedback loop isn't present in Govt, and without it I think all Commercial companies would do exactly the same thing (human nature). We are re-deriving from first principles why the tech business model exists at all: massive R&D costs are amortized across a large number of customers to create affordability and scale. 's article, "Don't get locked up into avoiding lock-in", provides a more robust way to think about these decisions: And it is important to remember that the goal of Open Source was never to avoid lock-in -- it was funded to commoditize someone's compliments. …see more
Remote working is one of the major reasons people want to switch careers to code. But it's not a good idea (edit: remote as in full wfh, including across multi timezones. I don't consider hybrid to be remote) Remote work takes a level of autonomy and skill that beginner programmers are unlikely to have. Plus the upsides are all personal and the downsides are all professional. Which is not a good way to start off a new professional career. Instead, I'd say look for remote coding roles after you've spent a few years learning as much as you can through direct interaction with experienced coders. If remote work is a preference and not a necessity, then park the preference for 2 years. Your future coder self will thank you. Feel free to ask my why in the comments! 👇 PS: I'm recording the latest episode of my podcast that summarizes my 13 years of flexible/hybrid and remote working experience. Watch out for that next week! …see more

How Twitter can help Retailers with Search Engine Optimization (SEO) A major benefit of Twitter Text-Mining is the ability to gauge how customers describe trends. For example, there is an increased trend in the term "90's fashion" being used online. By tagging item names, descriptions, and images with the term "90's fashion" a retailer could better their chance of being seen. To conclude, there's a lot to extract from Tweets about consumer preference, and learning to do so can help retailers succeed. …see more

Building An Online Presence is an Investment, Not a Cost! . . . Let me explain why this needs to be reminded again & again. Many business owners hesitate to invest in a good website, mostly because they are unaware of the ROI a website can create for their business. They often have these misconceptions: “We don’t need a website; we get a lot of referrals.” “Our clients approach us directly.” And even if they decide to get one built, they usually cut corners and try to invest the least amount of money or effort possible. After helping businesses go from 0 to 1 in building their digital presence for over 5 years, I can tell you how a great website can be a game-changer. Let’s take an example of a website for a real estate business and how it helps the business grow → Increased Credibility By showcasing social proofs and client testimonials specific to real estate transactions, we establish trust and credibility among potential clients, making them more confident in our services. Improved Property Listing Management A website provides centralized listing management, easy organization, display, and listing updates. Enhanced Lead Generation Through strategic lead capture forms and hyper-local content about the property listings & their neighborhoods, the website becomes a lead generation powerhouse. Higher Conversion Rates Optimizing property listing pages for higher conversion rates ensures that website visitors are more likely to take action, such as scheduling a property viewing or requesting more information, leading to increased conversions and successful deals. Data-Driven Decisions Analyzing user search behavior on the website provides valuable insights into which properties are in high demand and which neighborhoods are garnering the most interest. Attract Great Talent A website that highlights your company culture, values, and success stories can significantly attract top agents and brokers. Comment below with your industry, and I'll reply on how investing in building a website can grow your business. …see more

Conversion rate optimization (CRO) is especially important for SaaS websites. Revenue growth depends on your ability to convert visitors to trials, trials to paying customers, and customers into long-term, loyal users. When we do CRO for SaaS websites, here’s what we focus on: 1. A landing page that sells the next step 2. A call to action for taking that step 3. A optimized way to take action (a form, for example) 4. A “thank you” experience that What would you add? …see more
🚀 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐞𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐞𝐭𝐢𝐧𝐠 𝐢𝐬 𝐝𝐞𝐚𝐝? 𝐓𝐡𝐢𝐧𝐤 𝐚𝐠𝐚𝐢𝐧! 🌟 Every conference, every client, and every sales pitch reminds me that people still doubt the power of email marketing. Yet, I can assure you that even without a proper strategy, emails can contribute a minimum of 5% to your top line. With a well-crafted plan, this can skyrocket to 15-20% of your monthly revenue. Here are the steps I always outline for my clients to maximize their email marketing potential: 1️⃣ 𝐒𝐞𝐭 𝐂𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐫 𝐄𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐓𝐚𝐫𝐠𝐞𝐭𝐬: Ensure you can track sales in GA4. 2️⃣ 𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐧𝐮𝐞 𝐒𝐩𝐥𝐢𝐭: Distinguish between revenue from manual campaigns and automated flows. Depending on the industry, flows can contribute 20-60% of total email revenue. 3️⃣ 𝐌𝐨𝐧𝐭𝐡𝐥𝐲 𝐅𝐥𝐨𝐰 𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐢𝐞𝐰: Analyze last month’s flows to identify where KPIs weren’t met and make necessary adjustments at each step. 4️⃣ 𝐃𝐞𝐟𝐢𝐧𝐞 𝐂𝐚𝐦𝐩𝐚𝐢𝐠𝐧 𝐆𝐨𝐚𝐥𝐬: Each email type (new arrivals, promotions, event invitations) should have a specific revenue target. Each email type will have a different target because a promotional email is not the same as an event invitation. Hence, you need to define revenue per email and evaluate performance monthly. 5️⃣ 𝐏𝐥𝐚𝐧 𝐀𝐡𝐞𝐚𝐝: Work on manual campaigns at least 30 days in advance. I usually recommend clients finish all monthly campaigns one month in advance. For example, today they should start working on August campaigns. Most marketing automation tools allow pre-scheduling. 6️⃣ 𝐖𝐞𝐞𝐤𝐥𝐲 𝐂𝐡𝐞𝐜𝐤-𝐢𝐧𝐬: Review the performance of flows and campaigns weekly. If they worked, ask yourself, "Shall we postpone that extra promotion we had next week?" If they didn’t work out, maybe we need to add an extra email next or the following week. Always have an emergency plan email ready to deploy quickly. Do you incorporate emails into your eCommerce strategy? What works for you? Share your suggestions for those still skeptical about email marketing. 💬👇 …see more

One of the hardest things to do as a founder is set aside dedicated “learning time”. As your company grows, so does your list of responsibilities. As someone who learns more from conversation and video than reading, I launched a podcast. Imagine if you could sit down every week with someone you’re curious to learn from and ask them questions for an hour. I view my podcast as “dedicated learning time”. Each week I get to chase my curiousities and share the insights with all of you. After filming 35+ episodes - here are the 3 main reasons why I think everyone should start a podcast: 1. Free learning! If you start a podcast for YOU, not only will it come off as more authentic, but you can use it to learn about the topics where your curiosity lies. and I have interviewed everyone from YouTubers like to brand founders like to SaaS founders like and amazing investors like . Why? Because they are all doing things I wanted to know more about. 2. Relationship Building Relationship 101: Give value before asking for anything in return. Giving someone a platform to tell their story is one of the easiest ways to provide value to people you are interested in building relationships with. The bigger your platform gets, the easier it’ll be to get guests you want to know. 3. Content and Personal Brand Building Think about how many interesting conversations you have in a week that aren’t caught on camera. With a podcast, you can record, repurpose, and distribute sound bites and clips from your conversations across the internet which will garner more eyeballs and grow your audience. Sounds crazy right? You can have fun, learn, build relationships, and grow an audience all at the same time! Start a podcast. Thank me later. If you’re new here, check out the . Revealing some exciting news about Season 2 in the coming weeks... …see more
Amazon listing conversion tip: Did you know there's a section on the listing most brands neglect? It's a small section but leads to a massive lost in sales over time. It's the video section, right before the reviews and below the Q&A. If this section isn't filled with videos about your product, Amazon starts to fill it with competitors over time. Before you ask "Is this section even important?" In short, yes. We surveyed 100 Amazon customers in 2022 about this section. 48 said they look at this section when making a purchasing decision. When we pressed further, their general response "It's like YouTube product review, but I don't have to leave Amazon." Huge. And the good news? Anyone can upload here. Doesn't have to be a previous customer. Here's the better news. You can control this. Get your brand ambassadors / UGC content creators and tell them to upload it here. 5 videos minimum so competitor videos get pushed to second page. Small changes, big momentum. …see more
🤔 What are the fundamentals of sales? Recently, I found myself reflecting on a discussion about the correlation between mastering the fundamentals and achieving better sales results. The consensus was clear: a solid grasp of the basics is indeed a stepping stone to enhanced sales performance. 🤨 So, I was irked that the conversation was overly focused on specific skills and tools. A quick search on 'fundamentals of sales' confirmed my suspicion, with results emphasizing customer focus, prospecting, qualifying, and the like. 📖 According to Webster, fundamental means "serving as an original or generating source." 👉 +Fundamentals are the foundation, not the skill itself. --- 🎯 What the fundamentals of sales really are: 1. Supportive Beliefs: Beliefs shaped by upbringing influence sales behaviors and success. 2. Lack of Need for Approval: Fear of being disliked inhibits essential sales skills. 3. Ability to Control Emotions: Emotional involvement diverts focus from the present moment. 4. Supportive Buy Cycle: Your buying behavior influences your selling style. 5. Comfortable Discussing Money: Focus on value, not price. 6. Handling Rejection: A strong self-image helps one understand rejection is not personal. --- It's important to remember that both experienced and new salespeople often grapple with these fundamentals. You're not alone in this journey. The path to improving sales starts with mastering these basics. What's your take on these fundamentals? I'd love to hear your insights. 🗨 Comment, like, share, and 🔔 subscribe if you found this insightful! Your engagement is what makes this community thrive. …see more
4 𝐂𝐨𝐥𝐝 𝐄𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥 𝐁𝐞𝐧𝐜𝐡𝐦𝐚𝐫𝐤𝐬 𝐑𝐞𝐯𝐞𝐚𝐥𝐞𝐝! (𝐓𝐨 𝐌𝐚𝐤𝐞 $5,000+/𝐦𝐨) One of the most common questions I get asked is: What benchmarks to aim first, while sending cold emails? Today, I'm dropping some industry benchmarks to help you measure your cold email success (and ultimately, scale and boost your revenue!). 1) 𝐀𝐜𝐜𝐨𝐮𝐧𝐭 𝐒𝐞𝐭𝐮𝐩: 𝐃𝐨𝐧'𝐭 𝐥𝐨𝐨𝐤 𝐥𝐢𝐤𝐞 𝐚 𝐬𝐩𝐚𝐦𝐦𝐞𝐫. ↳ Limit yourself to 3 email accounts per domain. ↳ This helps manage deliverability and keeps your domain reputation intact. 2) 𝐖𝐚𝐫𝐦𝐮𝐩: 𝐁𝐮𝐢𝐥𝐝 𝐚 𝐬𝐭𝐫𝐨𝐧𝐠 𝐬𝐞𝐧𝐝𝐞𝐫 𝐫𝐞𝐩𝐮𝐭𝐚𝐭𝐢𝐨𝐧 𝐟𝐢𝐫𝐬𝐭. ↳ Initiate the warm-up for at least 2-3 weeks before sending cold emails. ↳ Send consistent 20 warm-up emails daily using default settings. ↳ NEVER switch off warm-up. 3) 𝐂𝐨𝐥𝐝 𝐄𝐦𝐚𝐢𝐥𝐢𝐧𝐠: 𝐅𝐨𝐜𝐮𝐬 𝐨𝐧 𝐥𝐞𝐚𝐝𝐬 𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐥𝐢𝐭𝐲 𝐨𝐯𝐞𝐫 𝐪𝐮𝐚𝐧𝐭𝐢𝐭𝐲. ↳ Create a hyper-targeted lead list, with personalized messages. ↳ Restrict sending to 30 cold emails per day per email account. ↳ Use Spintax to avoid spam filters and ensure higher deliverability. 4) 𝐏𝐞𝐫𝐟𝐨𝐫𝐦𝐚𝐧𝐜𝐞 𝐌𝐞𝐭𝐫𝐢𝐜𝐬: 𝐀𝐧𝐚𝐥𝐲𝐳𝐞 𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐬𝐞 𝐧𝐮𝐦𝐛𝐞𝐫𝐬 𝐜𝐥𝐨𝐬𝐞𝐥𝐲. ↳ Aim For: 1 Positive Response per 200 Cold Emails Sent. ↳ Aim For: 1 Closed Deal Per 2500 Cold Emails Sent. Lastly, remember, these are just benchmarks. So, as your revenue grows via cold emails you can refine your strategy based on your specific audience and goals. P.S. - Happy Cold Emaling! :) …see more
Why is CONTINUOUS sales enablement critical to scaling Cloud GTM? Kate K., Sr. Director, Global AWS Alliance at JFrog explained her 360 degree enablement strategy on the course hosted by Ongoing Seller Enablement is Key: ✔ Cloud marketplaces (MP) could be central to your company's success. They can help sellers close deals faster and meet or exceed quotas. However, cloud GTM is NOT a primary focus for sellers, who concentrate on their accounts and customers. ✔ Therefore it’s Alliance leaders goal to ensure sellers grasp the benefits and importance of MPs. But how? Here are Kate's 10 Rules of Effective Sales Enablement: 1️⃣ Regular and Continuous Efforts: Understand seller focus areas and keep cloud strategies top-of-mind without overwhelming their inboxes. Help them integrate cloud GTM early in sales cycle 2️⃣ Go Beyond One-off Sessions: Include scheduled enablement calls, join QBRs, and maintain consistent communication. Ongoing sessions and follow-ups are vital to prevent “out of sight, out of mind” issue 3️⃣ Deliver Enablement in Various Formats: Use short on-demand videos, longer recordings, and in-person events to cater to different learning preferences 4️⃣ Create Easy-to-Reference Guides: Create cheat sheets and central source of truth for sellers on key topics, e.g. “how to co-sell” or “GTM via MPs” 5️⃣ Establish Central Communication Channels: Use platforms like Slack to send Cloud GTM updates and facilitate collaboration and marketplace experience sharing among sales teams 6️⃣ Provide Guidance for Co-Selling: Offer support on how to win in co-sell calls, including what questions to ask, how to show up, and what NOT to do 7️⃣ Leverage Customer Stories and References: Use success stories to build credibility with sellers and get them excited. Compelling customer examples can help sellers internalize how MPs can expedite deal closures 8️⃣ Identify and Leverage Successful Sellers as Advocates: Boost credibility by inviting sellers successful in Cloud GTM to share their stories in regular meetings. Developing internal advocates creates powerful peer influence. You can then across different motions or industry focuses can also be effective, ensuring relevance 9️⃣ Conduct Research for Sellers: Gather insights to empower sellers before engaging in conversations with key stakeholders at the cloud provider 1️⃣ 0️⃣ Seek and Act on Feedback: Encourage open communication and actively incorporate feedback from sellers and sales leadership to support them where they need it the most Implementing ongoing sales enablement is essential for scaling Cloud GTM effectively. By integrating regular training, providing accessible resources, and fostering collaboration, you can get sales teams excited and aligned with MPs. This can help them meet quotas, make customers more successful and significantly contribute to company growth. How are you enabling your sales teams to excel in Cloud GTM? …see more

10 (Honest) Steps to Integrate AI Into Your Business 1. Start with your business goals. What is stopping you achieve them? Write those challenges down. (Problem-centricity not tech-centricity) 2. Appoint an AI Champion (if you’re a small business) or AI Task Force (if you’re bigger). They’ll do all the steps below. 3. Do a temperature check - how are your people feeling about AI? Confused? Scared? Excited? Write any concerns down. 4. Now, get that list of challenges from step 1. See if there are any AI tools that can help. (future tools is a great start) 5. There are? Fab. Experiment. Test them. Properly. Push their limits, find where they break. 6. Go back to step 3’s list of concerns. Educate, motivate, reassure. Build excitement. Don’t try and do this without the buy-in of your people. 7. Roll out one tool at a time. Not a huge, confusing armoury, just the one. 8. Incentivise play and experimentation with this tool: set challenges, gamify. 9. Measure everything: time saved, ROI, changes in people’s feelings, glitches, limitations. Apply this learning to everything you do next. 10. Find the next challenge and the next tool. Remember, AI won’t help with everything. Once you’ve mastered off the shelf tools, your next 3 steps are: - Building automated workflows of stacked tools - Building GPTs/Assistants - Building autonomous AI agents …more on those soon. 💬 Where are you in your AI journey? ❓ Have I missed anything? PS If you need some help with that motivation and education, I’m taking new AI training bookings from mid-July. PPS I’ve got a great guide coming out this week for how to appoint your AI task force. …see more

Quelle que soit l'issue du scrutin législatif, un nouveau gouvernement à 3 semaines des JO, ça va être sportif!..et côté culture, avec potentiellement un(e) 6eme ministre en 7ans, la France à déjà la médaille d'or de l'instabilité gouvernementale. Au moins une...🇨🇵 Pari risqué quand on voit les exemples passés de la dissolution de 1997, de la constitution Européenne de 2005 ou du Brexit anglais. Ce qui m'intéresse surtout, c'est de voir LinkedIn France muer progressivement d'un réseau purement corporate à l'origine, en une sorte de forum politique, au sens grec du terme (polis=la cité), c'est à dire un forum de questions de société. Il est de moins en moins question de business, et de plus en plus de développement personnel, RSE, "valeurs", ce qui appelle logiquement à deborder sur le modèle sociétal que proposent les partis politiques. Étonnamment, je retrouve moins cette extension de LinkedIn dans la partie anglo-saxonne de mon réseau. Au UK , le Premier Ministre a convoqué en urgence des elections le 4 juillet sans polémique majeure. J'y vois d'abord la faillite des autres réseaux dits "sociaux", - Twitter, un noman's Land ou les haters-snipers anonymes vous tirent dessus à la moindre prise de position - Facebook, un reseau agé en état de mort cérébrale. Encore utile pour les petites annonces et les associations locales - Instagram, royaume de l'image retouchée, des "influenceurs' a la solde des marques et du narcissisme triomphant -.Snapchat et Tiktok , ou la vacuité des contenus vidéos "augmentés" de filtres débiles semble la règle.. Urgent d'en réduire la consommation nocive pour les adolescents. Reste donc LinkedIn comme dernier espace de débat ou les gens se modèrent tous seuls, car leur identité est connue, et leur ambition professionnelle les retient souvent de prises de positions trop clivantes. J'observe néanmoins que de plus en plus cadres et dirigeants d'entreprise commencent à exprimer publiquement des positions politiques personnelles. Pensez vous que ce soit le rôle d'un(e) dirigeant(e) d'entreprise ou d'un collectif? Doit-il(elle) descendre dans l'arène politique ou rester neutre et impassible comme le Roi d'Angleterre?. Never explain, never complain... 🫱preneur de votre avis sur le sujet. Quoi qu'il en soit, aux urnes citoyens!..., car la meilleure façon de peser dans le débat public, ce n'est pas de poster ni de pester, mais de voter!🗽 …see more See translation

StudioHawk wanted to build and scale its sales channel. [10 months later: 175% increase in deals won, 9x pipeline] How did we get there? Here’s a quick breakdown (and a link to a detailed case study for those interested). It all started with understanding what was stopping them from scaling quickly. Three things: 1/ Too much “key person” risk. 2/ Lack of a “dedicated” sales team. 3/ Lack of a “consistent” & “diversified” marketing engine. In Norway, you are given “Publication Points” for publishing. Now, one scientist has published 871 papers in 5 years. “Scientific publications yields publication points, which the Ministry of Education use as basis for reallocation of funds between institutions”. How points are calculated: 1. Publication weight: Journal gives 0.7-3 points, books: 5-8 points. 2. International co-authoring is x1.3 multiplier 3. Several institutions in one paper means the points are divided between them. I guess that collaborations are not encouraged. 📍 Filippo is the Norway’s most productive researcher. He produces a new study every two to three days (on average). “He has reportedly expressed aspirations to become Europe’s most productive researcher” - Retraction Watch. Now, as Retraction Watch says, Filippo is accused of: - publishing duplicate studies in multiple journals - including references to irrelevant studies - producing articles that contain keywords from advertisements from paper mills” Steineide Refseth (librarian from INN University in Norway): “Researchers are evaluated too much based on how much they have published instead of the quality of what they have published, and that the Norwegian publication points system may have contributed to this.” An average scientist in Norway got 1.25 points in 2022. Filippo got 407 points from 2019 to 2022. 📍 My thoughts: This is another example of ‘overpublishing’. Quantity goes first and foremost. Numbers ‘win’. But for what? For respect? For money? For impact? Even with a large group, publishing more than 20-30 papers per year makes little sense. Quality per paper drops. Big numbers mean less time spent on each study. Quality of PhD education drops. Students have to produce papers instead of deep research. The impact drops. When a study is spread out across lots of papers, it becomes too thin to notice. Scientist ≠ printing machine. There should be NO push to publish lots of papers. Not from funders, nor from universities. This is why funding policies are so central to HOW and WHAT we publish. [see the story in the links below] …see more

The founders of fast-growing European startups often get asked if they plan to relocate their headquarters to the US to tap into deeper pools of capital and talent. , the CEO of autonomous driving startup , is no exception. Last month, his London-headquartered startup raised $1bn from investors including , and ('s parent company). Since then, several journalists have asked him if he's going to move the company to Silicon Valley, or somewhere else. "Our headquarters is of course remaining and staying in London," Kendall said at on Monday. "I love the environment here," he added. "The thing that's special about London for me is that it's a tech superpower but it's not tech dominated. It's diverse, it's culturally rich. Almost a third of my company, including me, are here on a visa." Wayve currently has offices in London, Silicon Valley and Vancouver, and Kendall said it's likely to expand further in order to support the automotive partnerships the company has. "That footprint needs to be global to address the world," said Kendall, who moved from New Zealand to complete a PhD at the prior to setting up Wayve. Elsewhere, AI lab DeepMind (now owned by Google) is another UK tech startup that chose not to relocate to Silicon Valley, despite pressure from early investors like PayPal billionaire Peter Thiel. In France, has kept its HQ in Paris after raising large sums. On the other hand, four French unicorns – , , and – shifted their HQs to the US, according to analysis. Algolia, a B2B software company, moved its main base to San Francisco in 2014 to participate in the acceleration programme. Co-founder and CTO told Sifted it helped his company raise money at better terms and attract more customers. , the Irish born co-founder of , told LinkedIn News last month that top tech startups can raise money from investors regardless of where they're headquartered. "If you have a good startup idea, you're going to be able to raise money for it," he said. What can the UK and Europe do to ensure the most promising tech firms stay put? Découvrez un nouvel article : La 5G en France : une adoption progressive malgré la domination de la 4G See translation
Random offers aren't the way to revenue stability Throwing random offers out there when you need a quick cash injection? I know you want more sales, but pumping out offer after offer isn't the secret. My guess is you sell some spots, feel on top of the world, just for it to come crashing down when the offer comes to a close. Because now you have to do it all AGAIN. You see other coaches throw out offer after offer and having huge success, so that must be the secret, right? It’s not. Understanding sales is crucial if you want to sell out your offers, every single time. If consistency and predictability in your income is what you want, then this is what you need to do: 1. Look at the bigger picture. Think about what you do and how you can solve your client’s problems in different ways. Look at it as stepping stones from point a-b. This will be the foundation for building a scalable (and sellable) offer suite. You need to know HOW to sell, WHEN to sell and WHERE to sell. 💸Different platforms require different sales approaches. 💸Each offer demands a tailored selling strategy. 💸You can't share identical content across all channels and expect the same success. 2. Stop focussing on quick cash injections and prioritize your monthly recurring revenue. This is NOT only in the form of payment plans. A good strategy for MRR should include ways for you to sell without posting 50x a day and selling your soul on 100-story sequences or launching a new offer every month. Revenue pathways need to be prioritized. This includes: 💸 Active offers 💸 Passive/Evergreen offers 💸 Sales Automations 3. Client retention: If you’re just throwing out random offers that have no clear problem they solve or ‘’next step’’ then your clients won’t know what to move into next. Having a clear pathway for clients to move through your offers will help you retain clients. And it’s easier to sell to someone who has already bought than to get someone to buy for the first time. 4. Your sales strategy for your different offers. The way you create and sell a masterclass is different to how you sell a Mastermind. Selling private coaching requires a different strategy than selling a group program, or course. Selling on stories is different from selling on lives. Sales isn't a one-size-fits-all approach and those who tailor their sales according to WHAT they are selling and WHERE they are selling see the most success. The days of posting the same piece of content everywhere and crossing your fingers are over. If you want to make daily sales, you need to create a solid sales strategy for every offer. Full stop. And in Revenue on Repeat we cover all of this. You will walk away from ROR knowing EXACTLY what to do to make sales a daily thing. We start on July 17th. 27 people have claimed their spots, are you next? Lifetime access. A tailored strategy for whatever you're selling next so that you actually make sales. Comment ROR for more info 🔥 …see more

They anticipate a sales experience that is intuitive, informative, and primarily online—preferring to interact with a salesperson only when necessary 2. These customers now expect relevant content to be available when, where, and how they need it. 3. They expect a brand's website to offer genuine value rather than just promotion. 4. They want a Frictionless Journey from the first click to a DEMO schedule. 5. They demand personalized interactions and content tailored to their specific needs and pain points. As a new B2B CMO or VP of Marketing your first 90 days are your most important. Here are 4️⃣ key objectives for every new B2B marketing leader that both Nick Tippmann 🏔️☁️ shares in his experience at , and what we’re seeing on the agency side at . 1️⃣ Due Diligence Do not confuse this with onboarding. It’s your responsibility to gain a deep understanding of brand narrative, product value, category insights, company profitability, sales metrics, and more. You cannot build a world-class marketing program with no benchmarks or context. 2️⃣ Data Integrity Find out where marketing dollars and resources are going, measure the ROI, hit the killswitch on every marketing initiative not producing pipeline and ROI, and recover that wasted spend back to your marketing budget. 3️⃣ MVP Experiments Your first win was recovering wasted spending back to the company. Your next win will come from making a strategic bet on a marketing initiative(s) and setting up benchmarks and roadmaps to validate it in the early stages. The worst mistake you can make as a new B2B marketing leader is betting the farm on a program with no positive signals or roadmap, and not hitting your target numbers. Instead, you should identify what positive signals validate a program in infancy, achieve those metrics, and then scale. 4️⃣ Communication with Senior Leadership Most B2B marketing programs get shut down way too early because the marketing leader does not communicate all the factors to senior leadership. The program details are usually vague with a massive request for budget right after. The more clarity and depth you can bring to senior leadership on what and when to expect results will give you the breathing room needed to actually validate and scale your program. …see more

Google's March 2024 Core Update: A Reckoning for Low-Quality Content & Spam The March 2024 Google Core Update is making waves, with some sites hit by manual actions or deindexing, while others remain unaffected. What's going on? Here's my take: Google is laser-focused on two things: - Low-quality content: AI-generated or not, content that lacks value and fails to provide information gain is being penalized. - Spam: From expired domain abuse to monetized spammy content, Google is cracking down hard. Who's at Risk? - Sites relying heavily on unvetted AI-generated content. - Sites with backlinks from dropped or spammy domains. - Sites monetizing unrelated third-party affiliate content. Have you been impacted? Check Google Search Console for significant drops in impressions and clicks since March 5th. Also, look for manual actions. What to do if you've been hit: - Assess the damage: Check GSC for deindexing or manual actions. - Identify the cause: Is it AI content, backlinks, or spammy practices? Take action: - For AI content: Audit, improve, or remove low-quality pages. - For backlinks: Build new, high-quality links from reputable sites. - For spam: Stop the practice and request reconsideration. Remember: Don't panic if you haven't been affected. Focus on creating people-first content that provides genuine value. Let me know your thoughts and experiences with the update! …see more
Interview hack no one talks about: At the end, the last question you should try to ask is “After everything we’ve discussed, what are some of things you like about me for this role?” The goal here is to leave on a high note and if they aren’t sharing much it’s all the feedback you need to know you weren’t right for the role. It is very rare that interviewers will give you negative feedback so take the advantage to hear some good things about you. ____________________________ P.S. On me demande à chaque fois quel budget mettre en ads ou comment savoir si c'est rentable ? Et bien j'ai décidé de créer un calculateur pour vous aider ⬇ Le fonctionnement est simple. Vous indiquez en input : - Objectif de CA - Panier moyen - Taux de marge brute - coût fixe - Taux de profit - Frais de prestataire (agence, freelance...) Vous obtenez en output : - Investissement maximum en ads (sans rogner sur votre profit) - ROAS breakeven - CAC breakeven - MER breakeven Le mot "Breakeven" fait référence au seuil de bascule à partir du moment où vous êtes rentable sur vos campagnes. Je vous ai également mis un glossaire avec les définitions et les méthodes de calcul de chaque KPI. Pour accéder au calculateur : 1. Like le post 2. Commente le post 3. Vérifie que l'on soit connecté pour que je puisse t'envoyer le calculateur en MP …see more See translation

“What’s the lead source on that?” This is the endless game. Automation, attribution, data, multi-touch, influence… But I’ve always found conversion source to be a much more interesting data point. If we acknowledge that there are dozens of touch points across paid media, earn media, owned media, sales outreach, and old-fashioned marketing, then the importance of original lead source degrades over time. Alternatively, if we build a system around what made that person convert to a meeting or sign up, then that story can be more inclusive of everything in marketing and sales, in terms of actual, meaningful and insightful attribution. Plus, when you have so many leads coming from ZoomInfo and those types of list building tools, does lead source truly suggest anything meaningful here? Or would you rather know if it was a sales email, trade show activation, or paid ad that brought them into your conversion funnel? Going even further, this approach allows you to build a hybrid attribution model between self-sourced attribution and conversion source. Since we did this, it’s helped us ask better questions, create content and calendaring, and know what motions are hitting and which aren’t. …see more

🚨 After a stint as an investment banker, Tania Hoeding moved into venture capital and today she's an investor at Prosus Ventures. She joins Sam Shead for VC Wednesdays, a weekly series featuring a Q&A interview with a venture capitalist. ✒ What's your one pet peeve in a startup pitch? With the rapid advances in AI, software and AI products are now easier and faster to build, resulting in increased competition across various sectors. Occasionally, I encounter founders who provide "salesy" or vague responses when asked about their differentiation. This answer is crucial. While perfect barriers to entry may not exist, investors expect founders to take competitive threats seriously and demonstrate strategic thinking on the matter. We know companies are already considering their differentiation, so clearly communicating this is essential. ✒ What kind of founders are you on the hunt for at the moment and why? We are always seeking founders with a unique vision, particularly those who have spent significant time in a specific industry and understand its pain points and solutions. Additionally, a transparent and honest relationship between VC and founder is crucial, enabling both sides to maximise the partnership. ✒ Which startup bet are you most proud of? We’re proud of all our investments. One that comes to mind is . Last year, we co-led the $60m series B round with into Corti, an AI-copilot for medical workers. As Corti sells into healthcare and this is a highly regulated industry, there was of course an added layer of diligence that we enjoyed exploring. We were impressed by how technically advanced the company was and is, having already built various models in-house, and by the creativity of the founding team to overcome the barriers to accessing healthcare data. The buzz around AI has driven more overall curiosity from everyone. It’s unlocked a new eagerness or willingness to explore new tools, and in many cases adopt AI, even in historically risk-averse industries such as healthcare. I'm excited to see how the space is going to evolve over the next few years and how tech adoption evolves in parallel. This is a space we’re closely following and see a big opportunity for innovation. …see more

Revisiting the biggest lie in sales: "The customer is always right." Let's face it—we've all encountered challenging clients. Yet, these interactions are not just roadblocks; they are stepping stones. Every objection, critique, and 'difficult' conversation is an untapped goldmine for honing your selling skills. Why? Comfort zones don't breed excellence. Challenged clients push us to analyze our approach, refine our pitch, and sharpen our problem-solving skills. They force us to listen more attentively, empathize more deeply, and negotiate more strategically. Imagine transforming every 'no' into a compelling reason to improve. Picture yourself embracing client feedback, not as criticism, but as invaluable insight that fuels your growth. Here's the twist: The customer isn't always right, but their impact on your sales evolution always is. Let's shift the narrative. Start seeing challenging clients as mentors in disguise. Engage with them, learn from them, and watch your selling skills soar to new heights. Ready to turn your next tough client interaction into a masterclass in sales? Share your thoughts or an experience where a challenging client helped you up your sales game! …see more

I’ll be honest, you would be pivoting multiple times before you find a market-fit. Here’s why - because you don’t know the problem. The first step of providing a solution in the market is to figure out the problem. You start a service business by assuming ‘x’ could be the problem. And you could be right. That’s the beauty of a service business - you got skills, you provide value. The game-changer is to differentiate yourself in the market. This is where it gets tough! So the easiest thing you could do is start executing and selling. The more you sell, deeper the market insights you get. Your initial set of clients will help you figure the problem in the market. That’s how you’d start shaping your solution. So, you’d go from your “assumed solution” to “market demanded solution” (demand side). That’s when you’d find a market fit. So start executing, embrace pivoting, and refine your offering based on market demands. ***** If you like this post, I run a newsletter sharing my journey of building a company from scratch. It is to help folks like us get over the cold start problem and embrace the world of entrepreneurship. Interested? …see more
Qui décide de la liste des émojis ? Ces petits symboles qui nous permettent d'illustrer nos conversations 💬, de signaler notre humeur (😉/😢/😏) ou de répondre sans un mot, d'un 👍 pour valider, ❤️ pour apprécier, ou 😂 pour signifier qu'on se bidonne (en réalité, il paraît que l'émoji des jeunes pour cela est 💀, genre "mort de rire"). Et bien c'est le Consortium Unicode qui est aux commandes. Une organisation à but non lucratif dédiée au développement du standard Unicode (tout ce qui peut être partagé sous forme de texte entre tous les logiciels et appareils de notre quotidien). Au cœur de cette mission : le Unicode Emoji Subcommittee. Ce sous-comité regroupe des représentants d’entreprises technologiques de premier plan (Apple, Google, Microsoft, Meta, Adobe, IMB, Amazon...) et des experts indépendants en linguistique et design. Toute personne ou organisation peut soumettre une idée pour un nouvel émoji, ou demander le retrait d'un émoji. Il y a quelques années, l'émoji "pistolet" a été remplacé par un émoji "🔫" (jouet). Et, récemment, un jeune britannique à lunettes de 13 ans a demandé le retrait de l'émoji 🤓, arguant que cet émoji renforçait le stéréotype "porteur de lunettes = nerd", ce qui n'est pas complètement faux. Ces propositions sont ensuite examinées par le sous-comité selon des critères stricts tels que la compatibilité, la fréquence d’utilisation prévue, et la diversité. Les propositions approuvées rejoignent une future version du standard Unicode, pour finalement apparaître sur nos appareils après mise à jour par les fabricants de logiciels et de matériel. C'est l'Académie Française des émojis 🤓 Mais que nous a annoncé Apple hier soir ? Le Concept IA du Mardi E07 👉 Genmoji ⁇ Pourquoi ? Parfois, on ne trouve pas l'émoji qui correspond pile-poil à ce que l'on veut dire. 🏭 Par qui ? Apple, pour ses logiciels et appareils propriétaires. 🤖 Quoi ? Apple nous dit : "Libérez-vous de l'Académie Internationale des Émojis, grâce à l'IA générative, vous pouvez désormais créer l'émoji que vous voulez pour l'utiliser dans iMessage". On peut se réjouir de pouvoir communiquer encore plus finement sa pensée ou son humeur avec des émojis totalement sur mesure. Mais, car j'ai quelques "mais" : 1. Cela flingue l'inter-opérabilité : "les émojis sur mesure, c'est uniquement entre utilisateurs Apple" alors que, comme vu plus haut, le catalogue d'émoji a été minutieusement maintenu comme un standard depuis des années. Les émojis à 2 vitesses, pas terrible. 2. Contre-intuitivement, je pense que cela limite la créativité. Car la contrainte est mère de créativité. Il n'y a pas d'émoji "fesses" ? Qu'à cela ne tienne, j'utiliserai l'émoji "pêche" 🍑. Quand tout émoji devient possible, aucun n'est plus jamais surprenant. 3. Un alphabet commun, même visuel, n'est-il pas une manière de vivre un peu mieux (S) ? Dommage de perdre cela parce qu'il me fallait absolument un émoji sur mesure, non ? …see more See translation

What I learned in my first month as a #fractionalCMO building high level strategy for 13 web3 clients at Coinbound: 1. Having exposure across many different web3 verticals, departments and tons of project startup evaluations has been incredibly beneficial to being able to fit all the tiny shards [see what I did there] of puzzle pieces together into a full picture quickly. 2. Understanding centralized compliance and licensure in the DeFi space and fundraising/ICO processes helps me set expectations for realistic timeline for messaging and target audiences. PS- yes, I will absolutely review and give feedback on your white paper, pitch deck and even let you practice your pitch/demo to me [ 😭 happy cry]. 3. Having a team of specialist and account managers that have initiative to improve processes and learn, think outside of the box, give feedback, freak out because they give a shit about their clients and quality of work...they deserve all the credit tbh. 4. Explaining that doing things quick does not mean getting instant results. You can market anything [insert something really dumb 🥦 ] but buyers resonate with the value, solution, benefits and community. Even hype memecoins need something in this arena. Tier 1 products have spent many years building their brands. 5. An hour long discovery session, a few TG messages, and a 10 page marketing strategy does not make me an expert at your product or a mind reader 🧠 . The most successful clients take time to integrate us in to their team communication so we are aware of pivots, roadmaps, events etc. Thinking this should actually be #1. 6. Personalized emails can increase open rates by up to 50% – here's how to make it work for your brand 👇 1) Segment your subscribers: Differentiate your email list based on customer behavior, such as purchase history, browsing habits, and engagement with previous emails. → Segment customers who have purchased within the last 30 days from those who haven't purchased in over six months. Tailor your messaging to re-engage the latter with special offers or reminders about the benefits of your products. 2) Personalize subject lines: Create subject lines that include the recipient's name or reference past purchases. Studies show that personalized subject lines can increase open rates by 26%. → Instead of a generic "Check out our new arrivals," try "John, new arrivals just for you!" or "Loved those shoes? Here are matching accessories!" 3) Tailored content: Use dynamic content blocks to personalize email content for different segments. For example, recommend products based on past purchases or show relevant content based on browsing behavior. → For a customer who frequently purchases sportswear, include recommendations for new sports equipment or apparel. If a shopper has been browsing a particular category, such as electronics, highlight related products or special offers in that category. 4) A/B testing: Continuously A/B test your email campaigns to find the most effective personalization strategies. Test different variables such as subject lines, content layout, and send times. → Test two versions of an email - one with a personalized subject line and one without. Compare open rates and use the winning subject line strategy in future campaigns. Similarly, test different call-to-action (CTA) placements to see which drives more clicks. 5) Analyze and adjust: Analyze the performance of personalized emails and adjust your strategy based on what you learn. → Monitor metrics such as open rates, click-through rates, and conversion rates for your personalized emails. If a particular type of personalized content consistently performs well, include more of it in future campaigns. Conversely, if a strategy is underperforming, adjust your approach based on the data. 🤔 How have you used personalization in your email campaigns, and what results have you seen? …see more

As entrepreneurs and marketers, we're constantly strategizing and planning ahead to ensure the success of our businesses. While it's easy to get caught up in the demands of the present, it's essential to recognize the long-term benefits of our efforts, especially in the realm of Search Engine Optimization (SEO). SEO isn't just about improving your website's visibility on search engines; it's a powerful tool that can significantly impact sales and business growth, particularly when executed strategically across seasons. Imagine this scenario: You diligently invest time and resources into optimizing your website and content for relevant keywords during one season, let's say spring. While you may not see an immediate spike in sales during that time, the groundwork you've laid can set the stage for significant success in the following season, like summer. Here's how doing the SEO legwork during one season can influence sales and business in the next: Increased Visibility Building Authority and Trust Long-Term Organic Traffic Anticipating Trends and Demand Competitive Advantage …see more

Ever wondered how an old story could actually help you sell software today? 🤔 I’m in Capri, Italy, and I just heard an amazing story that connects Italian culture directly to selling software. While making ravioli with some locals, we got into a chat about French onion soup. Turns out, it was originally an Italian dish, not French! This mix-up has lasted for centuries. Why am I telling you this? Because it shows how powerful stories are. The locals here are still so passionate about setting the record straight. Their energy shows that a good story can really stick with people and stir up strong feelings. Think about using stories in your sales. They grab people’s emotions and can push them to make decisions—exactly what we need in sales. Check out my latest training video where I discuss how important storytelling is in sales and how to use it to grab your customers' attention and close more deals. In today's business world, where competition is fierce and clients are becoming increasingly demanding, an effective lead-generation strategy is critical to the success of any company. A proper understanding of the needs and pain points of your target audience is the key to creating compelling marketing messages that can capture the attention of potential clients and turn them into real leads. Sarah recently asked me this question, and here's what I had to say. Sarah: "Hey Dmitry, I've been reading up on effective lead gen strategies and something jumped out at me - the importance of really understanding our target market's pain points. This article says the hardest but most crucial step is pinpointing the specific needs our products solve." Me: "You're right, that is key. If we don't have a clear grasp of the problems we can solve for potential clients, our marketing messages are going to miss the mark." Sarah: "Exactly. It recommends looking at client feedback, support tickets, and even industry forums to identify common challenges. Then we can position what we offer as the solution." Me: "Smart approach. We should analyze our most successful projects over the past few years - what types of clients did we serve best? What were their key needs we addressed well?" Sarah: "Good call. If we can find patterns in the industries, company sizes, roles of the decision-makers, and business needs for our top projects, that gives us a template for an ideal client profile to target." Me: "Precisely. Then we verify that the profile is scalable by looking at how many similar prospective companies and contacts we could potentially reach out to on LinkedIn, email campaigns, etc. If it's in the thousands, we're in business!" Sarah: "Love this data-driven way to laser-focus our lead gen efforts. I'll start pulling reports on our biggest wins to analyze. This should sharpen our targeting." This dialogue emphasizes the importance of thoroughly analyzing the needs of your target audience and developing a data-driven lead-generation strategy. By scrutinizing successful past projects, identifying patterns, and testing the scalability of the target profile, a company can effectively target its marketing efforts and maximize its impact on potential clients. Using such a systematic and data-driven approach allows companies to spend lead generation resources wisely, increasing the chances of success in attracting new clients and growing their business. …see more
The number 1 reason most cold emailers fail: They focus on learning, not executing. → Reading every book on cold emailing. → Spending weeks crafting the “perfect” email template. → Obsessing over the latest trends before sending a single email. The result? No progress. Here's what you should do instead: 1. Focus on one goal ↳ Get your first response. 2. A/B test everything: ↳ Subject lines, CTAs, offers. ↳ Learn by doing. 3. Send emails consistently: ↳ Volume over perfection. 4. Iterate quickly: ↳ Adjust based on what works ↳ And what doesn’t. 5. Analyze results ↳ Use data to refine your approach. Stop trying to learn before you act. Start executing while you learn. Consistent, daily action is how you discover what really works. PS: I'm testing new subject lines today. What about you? …see more
Leaked Google Search API Documents… A very vocal point of view I see in various SEO media boils down to: “Google is cheating, so we must, too. Let’s use clickbait and all the dirty tricks!” Well, you definitely can. Who am I to tell you otherwise… But what I actually consider important parts of the story: 1️⃣ Links really matter less—but one still needs them. Google takes into account the speed of link growth to a website—here, too, everything is clear. Links should be built up carefully, regularly, and strategically. No boosting a small B2B SaaS website with 100 of them once a month! Google likes quality links. It's better to have two quality brand ones than 15 random trash ones. 2️⃣ Clicks from real people and site navigation (“behavioral metrics”) matter the most. Exactly as I was saying in my previous post about the typical errors in SEO. Oh, and the third part, which was not in the papers: 3️⃣ 𝗗𝗼𝗻’𝘁 𝗯𝗲𝘁 𝗲𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘆𝘁𝗵𝗶𝗻𝗴 𝗼𝗻 𝗼𝗻𝗲 𝘀𝗼𝘂𝗿𝗰𝗲 𝗼f 𝗹𝗲𝗮𝗱𝘀 Google, SEO, whatever. One change in the algo and you are screwed 🤦‍♀️ …see more

Here is a quick rundown of my recent sales memo. Thought to share with fellow sales leaders and ask if anything I missed. Please add your 2 to 20 cents in comments Let's face it, traditional sales calls can feel like a one-sided monologue. You rattle off features, benefits, and prices, hoping something sticks. The key lies in a holistic approach. Your sales call should be a dynamic exchange that explores your prospect's unique needs and challenges. Here's how to make it happen: Focus on Them, Not You: It's not about your product; it's about how it solves their problems. Ask insightful questions to uncover their pain points and goals. Become a Trusted Advisor: Show genuine interest in their business and offer helpful insights, even if it doesn't directly lead to a sale. This establishes you as a valuable resource. Embrace the Two-Way Street: Listen actively and respond thoughtfully to their concerns. The conversation should flow naturally, with both parties contributing. Creating Value Before the Close. Offer Free Consultations: Use the call to conduct a mini-audit of their current situation and provide actionable recommendations. Share Relevant Resources: Send them articles, case studies, or white papers that address their specific challenges. Connect Them with Others: If their needs fall outside your expertise, introduce them to someone who can help. People buy from those they trust and see as valuable partners. By fostering genuine connections and creating value upfront, you'll be well on your way to closing more deals and building lasting relationships. …see more

Educate, Don't Just Sell ↳ Highlight how your SaaS product solves real problems. ↳ Share success stories and case studies. 2. Nurture Your Leads ↳ Not everyone is ready to buy - offer free trials, webinars, and valuable content. ↳ Build trust and loyalty first. 3. Personalization Matters ↳ Tailor your outreach and follow-up. ↳ Understand your prospect's pain points better than they do. 4. Data-Driven Approach ↳ Use analytics to understand what's working. ↳ Adjust strategies based on concrete insights. 5. Automate, Automate, Automate ↳ Use tools to streamline outreach and follow-up. ↳ Save time to focus on meaningful interactions. 14 Brutal truths you need to hear as a CEO: 1- You don’t have a “working from home” issue; you have a trust issue. 2- What you call “process” is usually unnecessary bureaucracy that slows down decision-making and reduces creativity. 3- Prioritizing short-term profits over employee well-being is a recipe for long-term disaster. 4- The worst time to offer a raise is when someone has already handed in their notice. 5- If your entry-level job requires experience... then it’s not an "entry-level" job. It’s a normal job paid poorly. 6- Most meetings are useless especially if everyone's secretly checking their email under the table. 7- Employee retention isn't just about salary; it's about respect, recognition, and opportunities for growth. 9- People don’t just quit jobs, they quit managers. 10- Company values on the wall mean nothing if they're not reflected in everyday actions. 11- Replacing someone will cost you more than to pay them what they were worth in the first place. 12- Trust isn't built through surveillance; it's built through transparency and mutual respect. 13- Your "urgent" tasks aren't as urgent as you think; learn to prioritize effectively. 14- Empty promises of promotions and raises will lead to resentment, not loyalty. Remember: If your team is your #1 priority, They’ll make your business theirs. ✌️ …see more

POWERFUL B2B MARKETING TECHNIQUE: "If you can articulate your prospect's problems better than they can themselves, they will naturally assume you have the solution". When our copywriters are crafting persuasive text for websites, ads and videos we use a set of proprietary techniques we call 'Code V'. One of the most powerful of these techniques is: 💎💎💎 Captivating attention right from the start of the piece by clearly articulating the target market's pain points. When you do this effectively, your audience FEELS that you understand them better than any of your competitors. They will FEEL an emotional connection with your brand. They'll be ready to hear more. Naturally, they assume you have the right solutions ... To do this well though, you need to TRULY understand the problems you solve for your clients at a very deep and precise level: 🔹How do THEY speak about their pain points? From their perspective, what is the cause of their pain? 🔹What are the exact words running through their psychology? 🔹What underlying emotion is driving them to solve it? 🔹What is their level of awareness of their problem? 🔹What solutions have they already tried and struggled with? KEY INSIGHT - you need to go deep and be specific. Most companies make the mistake of articulating surface-level problems only - so their marketing sounds exactly like all of their competitors. When executed correctly, the impact is powerful. However, it's NOT a manipulative technique. Because when you are one of the very few that have cared enough to really spend the effort on understanding your customers at that level of specificity... You will naturally be the provider to bring them the most value. . . . . …see more
